awd_titl_txt: CRII: SCH: A Computational Toolbox for Analysis of Big Brain Data
awd_abstract_narration:
The brain is our most complex and least understood organ. Due to the recent proliferation of large public neuroimaging data repositories, researchers have access to an unprecedented amount of data, but in many ways the amount of data has surpassed our abilities to analyze it. With pressing health questions attracting the interest of scientists, clinicians, and engineers, we have an urgent need for computational tools that integrate the methods and expertise of different fields. This project seeks to advance the analysis of big brain data by developing, using, and sharing novel open-source computational tools for the modeling and analysis of cortical thickness, an indicator of healthy brain development. Through the analysis of two large data sets containing over 500 individual scans, a baseline for cortical thickness variation throughout healthy development will be generated. Numerical simulations will also shed light on the effect of the mechanical forces that give rise to the brain?s unique shape. The computational tools developed will be made available for use by other researchers to further leverage existing open access databases of MRI scans. Beyond that, this project has the potential to produce new insights with clinical applications in the analysis of neurological disorders such as Autism Spectrum Disorder, Alzheimer's Disease, and Parkinson's Disease. Alongside this trans-disciplinary project, the team will also develop a student-written blog, intended for the general public, on interesting investigations in the field of biomechanics.

Gyrification, or the process by which the brain develops its characteristic wrinkles and folds, is the result of both biological processes and mechanical forces. These elements, tightly coupled and affecting each other, affect both the form and function of the brain. This project will increase the biological fidelity of the finite element simulations used to model gyrification by representing cerebrospinal fluid pressure, neuronal apoptosis, and synaptic pruning through the development of new material models that describe heterogeneous, anisotropic, growing and remodeling tissue. These computational simulations will generate a deeper understanding of the role of mechanical forces in the evolution of cortical thickness, which varies regionally both within and between individuals. By introducing a new metric of interest that allows for the characterization of thickness variations on arbitrarily small regions, this project will develop new computational tools for the analysis of within-subject and between-subject variations of cortical thickness and the characterization of these patterns in healthy development. The successful completion of this research will result in novel computational tools for neurological imaging analysis of big brain data in the many public neuroimaging databases, generating additional value out of existing resources.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Led by the PI, Dr. Maria Holland, the CoMMaND (Computational Mechanics of Morphology at Notre Dame) Lab is situated at the intersection of computation, mechanics, and biology. Gyrification, or the process by which the brain develops its characteristic wrinkles and folds, is the result of both biological processes and mechanical forces. These elements, tightly coupled and affecting each other, affect both the form and function of the brain. The goal of this CRII proposal was to advance the analysis of big brain data by developing, using, and sharing novel open-source computational tools for the analysis of cortical thickness as an indicator of healthy brain development. 

In Aim 1, we designed advanced computational mechanics simulations to investigate the biomechanics of gyrification.  First, we considered the effect of surface pressure on bilayered instabilities, which is analogous to the pressure exerted by cerebrospinal fluid pressure on the brain (Darayi & Holland 2020 International Journal of Non-linear Mechanics).  We also created a novel computational model of the growing brain in order to determine the extent to which preferential growth in gyri or sulci contributes to the thickness difference between the two regions (Wang et al. 2021 Journal of Biomechanics and Modeling in Mechanobiology).  Finally, we wrote a review paper discussing some of the challenges and opportunities for the computational mechanics community in the modeling of brain development, including the effects of cerebrospinal fluid, synaptic connections, and cortical neuron growth and death (Darayi et al. 2022 Journal of Biomechanics).  

Aim 2 focused on the development of an open-source pipeline for cortical thickness analysis.  This work resulted in curveball, our software for the normalization and smoothing of cortical surfaces, the generation of surface-hugging alpha surfaces, and the calculation of cortical thickness and a number of other measures of topology and geometry.  This code has been made available on Github (github/mholla/curveball).

Finally, for Aim 3 we have characterized healthy patterns of gyral-sulcal cortical thickness ratio throughout the brain and throughout early post-natal development (Holland et al. 2020 European Physical Journal).  Next, we considered the relationships that govern local cortical thickness patterns.  We first identified shape index as a unique metric capable of distinguishing not only gyri and sulci, but also in determining the amount of tangential folding in a given location.  We published a study on local variations of cortical thickness in the human brain (Demirci & Holland 2022 Human Brain Mapping).  Among other things, this is the first local, three-dimensional analysis of cortical thickness patterns in the brain.  We've found that curvature measures serve as simple indicators of the local topology of the brain and correlate strongly with cortical thickness.  For example, convex points are thicker than concave points, and outer points are thicker than inner points.  Combining those, we also found that exterior convex points are the thickest and interior concave points the thinnest.  This suggests that there is a spectrum of folds in the brain, containing a lot of information about the arrangement of the cortex, rather than a strict binary between gyri and sulci.  A second paper examining the scaling of these thickness patterns across 12 primate species was recently submitted for publication (Demirci, Hoffman, & Holland, submitted).  

In total, we have published 5 peer-reviewed articles on our findings, with another manuscript submitted, and have presented the results nearly 20 times at over a dozen venues.  More importantly, we have made the code associated with all of our publications available to the public on Github (see github/mholla).  

Finally, this project also supported the development of the Biomechanics in the Wild website, for the training of undergraduate students in science communication while increasing public awareness of biomechanics.  It currently has over 130 posts (including text, video, and audio posts) introducing fascinating topics in biomechanics, and regularly receives over 4000 visitors each month.
